facts.text: The parties were married on May 27, 1955.
The appellant lived with the first respondent for four years and a half; parties last resided together at Bareilly.

First respondent filed suit for dissolution of marriage/divorce or in alternative judicial separation, alleging appellant living in adultery with Chandra Prakash Srivastava (married to cousin of appellant), cruelty.
Appellant denied adultery, sexual intercourse with Chandra Prakash Srivastava, and cruelty.
Trial court held no living in adultery, no proved sexual intercourse with Chandra Prakash Srivastava, even if any it was condoned, no cruelty under s.10(1)(b); dismissed petition.

Allahabad High Court (judgment dated January 7, 1964, First Appeal No. 289 of 1961) held no living in adultery under s.13(1)(i), no illicit intimacy in May/June 1958, but sexual intercourse in 1955 based on two letters by Chandra Prakash Srivastava, no condonation; no cruelty under s.10(1)(b); granted divorce under U.P. amendment to s.13(1)(viii).
Special leave granted on August 25, 1964; first respondent remarried on July 2, 1964, son born May 20, 1965.

First respondent knew of alleged illicit relations in June/July 1955 or 1956; continued to live with appellant, son born 1957; sexual relations up to October 1958; willing to keep appellant after May/June 1958 at instance of friends.
Two letters (Ex. 2 and Ex. 3) written by Chandra Prakash Srivastava to appellant in 1955; appellant denied receiving them or sending any.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant had been living in adultery or had sexual intercourse with Chandra Prakash Srivastava after marriage.
Whether the appellant treated the first respondent with cruelty under s.10(1)(b).
Whether divorce could be granted under U.P. amendment to s.13(1)(viii) without prior decree of judicial separation.
Whether there was condonation of any alleged adultery under s.23(1)(b).
Whether special leave should be revoked due to first respondent's remarriage.

petitioner_arguments.text: No adultery or sexual intercourse with Chandra Prakash Srivastava; no cruelty.
No duty to inform first respondent of intent to apply for special leave; first respondent took risk by remarrying without verifying.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: ss.15 and 28 of Hindu Marriage Act

respondent_arguments.text: Sexual intercourse in 1955 proved by two letters; no condonation; entitled to judicial separation under s.10(1)(f) and divorce under U.P. amended s.13(1)(viii).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.10(1)(f), s.13(1)(i), U.P. amendment to s.13(1)(viii)

respondent_arguments.text: Revoke special leave as remarried believing no challenge, son born; negligence by appellant.
Grant judicial separation instead of divorce if needed.

court_reasoning.text: Dismissed application to revoke special leave; first respondent took risk by remarrying without verifying no special leave application filed; ss.15, 28 do not prevent special leave.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Party cannot deprive losing party of special leave chance by immediate remarriage.

court_reasoning.text: Agreed with courts below: no living in adultery under s.13(1)(i); no cruelty under s.10(1)(b).

Two letters by Chandra Prakash do not prove sexual intercourse in 1955; improper but not evidence of adultery; appellant denied; intrinsic evidence shows unreciprocated feelings; Chandra Prakash not stranger.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere letters from male relation insufficient without reciprocation proof.

court_reasoning.text: U.P. amendment to s.13(1)(viii) requires prior judicial separation decree; sub-clause (b) not independent; cannot grant divorce forthwith assuming judicial separation ground.
court_reasoning.key_observation: First judicial separation, then divorce if 2 years or exceptional hardship/depravity.

court_reasoning.text: Even if sexual intercourse in 1955, condoned under s.23(1)(b): first respondent knew 1955/56, continued cohabitation, sexual relations to Oct 1958, son born 1957, kept wife post-1958 at friends' instance.

holdings.text: No proof of adultery or sexual intercourse with Chandra Prakash Srivastava.
U.P. amended s.13(1)(viii) requires prior judicial separation decree for divorce.
Condonation bars any decree even if adultery proved.

precedents_cited.relevance: On condonation involving forgiveness confirmed by reinstatement in desertion context.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Marriage Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Grounds for judicial separation and divorce; condonation bar; appeal rights; remarriage after decree.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Marriage (Uttar Pradesh Sanshodhan) Adhiniyam, No. XIII of 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended ground for divorce after judicial separation decree.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court decree of divorce set aside; no decree of divorce or judicial separation granted to first respondent; application to revoke special leave dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "the mere fact that some male relation writes such letters to a married woman, does not necessarily prove that there was any illicit relationship between the writer of the letters and the married woman who received them."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects letters as proof of adultery.

key_quotes.text: "it was for the first respondent to make sure whether an application for special leave had been filed in this Court and he could not by marrying immediately after the High Court's decree deprive the appellant of the chance to present a special leave petition."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Sub-clause (b) can only apply after a decree for judicial separation has been passed and it is not open to a court to apply that clause and give a divorce forthwith."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets U.P. amendment requiring prior judicial separation.
